name: First-Year Seminar: The Heart of the Play: Fundamentals of Acting, Playwriting, and Collaboration
desc: This seminar is designed to get the student doing theatre, sparking creativity, and making connections with the deeper lessons of this dynamic art form.  Students will write, stage, and perform their own 10-minute plays.

name: First-Year Seminar: Psychology of Clothes: Motivations for Dressing Up and Dressing Down
desc: The course seeks to help students find ways to articulate their own motivations for dress and then apply the ideas they have discovered to the ways in which individuality as well as group attitudes are expressed through clothing. Honors version available

name: First-Year Seminar: Staging America: The American Drama
desc: This seminar examines American drama from its colonial origins to the present as both a literary and commercial art form. The focus throughout will be on the forces that shaped American drama as well as drama's ability to shed light on the national experience. Honors version available

name: First-Year Seminar: All the World's a Stage: Drama as a Mirror of Society
desc: This seminar examines how theatre evolves from and reflects the society that generates it, and how understanding that society can enrich our responses to plays.

name: First-Year Seminar: Spectacle in the Theatre
desc: This course examines how the theatrical designer uses scenery, costumes, and lighting to help create a production. Students will apply these techniques in creating their own design projects.

name: First-Year Seminar: The Inherent Qualities of Theatrical Space
desc: This course examines what elements contribute to the theatricality of space. Through research and creative projects, students will gauge how a space informs what goes on inside it.

name: First-Year Seminar: Documentary Theatre
desc: This course explores the political and social ramifications of documentary theatre in the United States. Students will investigate a local community of their choosing and create an interview-based performance. Honors version available

name: First-Year Seminar: Rediscovering the Mind-Body Connection
desc: This seminar will focus on developing our unique mind-body connection. By encouraging small and large changes in behavior students will learn how their body is used to create their world.

name: First-Year Seminar: Style: A Mode of Expression
desc: This seminar studies the elements of design in their pure form, surveys a history of period styles and theatre, and identifies their causes. Honors version available

name: First-Year Seminar: Ecology and Performance
desc: This seminar will guide students through researching, developing, and producing new performance works inspired by socio-ecological issues. This task involves student-directed research and experiential learning. Students will integrate an understanding of performance techniques, green theatre
Prereqs: and notions of sustainability into an ecologically-driven work for performance.

name: First Year Seminar:  Special Topics
desc: This is a special topics course. Content will vary.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Perspectives in Drama
desc: A survey of plays from the Greeks to the present, analyzed through such elements of the dramatic text as action, character, structure, and language. Honors version available

name: Perspectives in the Theatre: Page to Stage
desc: A survey of the interrelationships of acting, directing, designing, and playwriting through the study of major periods of theatrical expression and representative plays. Honors version available

name: Perspectives in World Drama
desc: A survey of non-Western drama and theatre with emphasis on the historical and aesthetic development of those regions. Honors version available

name: Play Analysis
desc: Development of the skill to analyze plays for academic and production purposes through the intensive study of representative plays. DRAM 120 is the first course in the major and the minor in dramatic art. Honors version available

name: Writing for the Screen and Stage
desc: Restricted course.  Dramatic writing workshop open only to students in the writing for the screen and stage minor.

name: Theatrical Auditions
desc: Permission of the instructor. Practice in the techniques necessary for successful auditions for the theatre.

name: Acting for Nonmajors
desc: Introduction to basic processes and techniques of acting for the stage.

name: Voice Training I
desc: Fundamental principles underlying the effective use of voice and speech in performance.

name: Acting the Song
desc: The course explores how to gain facility in expression and truthfulness in action while communicating through a dramatic song. Challenges include how to navigate a scene that moves into song and how to manage breath and vulnerability in performance. Permission of the instructor required.

name: Acting for the Screen and Stage
desc: The course focuses on developing acting techniques for use in front of the camera and the way they are differentiated from those used on stage.

name: Beginning Acting for the Major
desc: Introduction to acting tools, emphasizing playing actions and pursuing an objective by personalized given circumstances. Performance work drawn from short scripted, improvised, and contemporary scenes.

name: Performers' Awareness
desc: This course focuses on developing body and mind awareness and undoing habits (including habits of thought) which restrict the performer.  The class explores strategies for reducing tension, re-discovering natural alignment, and replacing self-judgement with self-confidence.

name: Movement for the Actor
desc: Introduction to physical training. Individual/group exercises explore relaxation, breath, concentration, flexibility, and imaginative response that become physical tools for acting. May include stage combat, juggling, mime, improvisation, games, and yoga.

name: Stagecraft
desc: General survey of materials, equipment, and processes used in technical theatre.

name: The Playful Actor: Theatre Games and Improvisation
desc: This course seeks to strengthen the powers of imagination, courage, spontaneity, and presence of the actor through theatre games and improvisation.

name: Building A Persuasive Persona Under Pressure
desc: This course will help develop the skills necessary to be an effective communicator, especially during stressful situations. Breathing techniques which enable us to listen with accuracy and empathy, and to speak compellingly with confidence, will be practiced. Mock scenarios and on-camera interviews will create real-to-life situations.

name: Technical Methods: Scenery
desc: DRAM 191 or 192 required for dramatic art majors. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to equipment, procedures, and personnel in the design and execution of plans for scenery, lighting, properties, and sound for theatrical productions.

name: Technical Methods: Costume
desc: DRAM 191 or 192 required for dramatic art majors. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to equipment, procedures, and personnel in the design and execution of costumes for theatrical productions.

name: Production Practicum
desc: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Required for the dramatic art major. Practicum in production with PlayMakers Repertory Company in costuming, scenery, lighting, sound, or theatre management.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Dramatic Art Projects
desc: Permission of the department. May be repeated for credit. Restricted to juniors and seniors majoring in dramatic art. Intensive individual work in major areas of theatrical production: design, technical, directing, acting, playwriting, management.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Studies in Western Drama
desc: A study of the thematic and formal developments of Western drama, tracing legacies from classical Greece to the contemporary stage.

name: Playwriting I
desc: Permission of the department. A practical course in writing for the stage with studio productions of selected works.

name: Acting for Nonmajors II
desc: A further exploration of basic processes and techniques of acting for the stage.

name: Voice Training II
desc: A continuation of DRAM 140.

name: Acting for the Camera
desc: The process of acting and its relationship to the technical and artistic demands of television/film production. Problems of continuity and out-of-sequence filming. Concentration and thinking on camera.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 135 or 150; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Intermediate Acting for the Major
desc: A deeper exploration of fulfilled actions prompted by an objective, with emphasis on developing techniques required by more formally structured texts such as Sophocles, Molière, Ibsen, Shaw, and Chekhov. .

name: Movement for the Actor II
desc: Development of balance, flexibility, strength, focus, grace, and precision through martial art of T'ai Chi Ch'uan. Emphasis on applying T'ai Chi principles to acting. Chinese philosophical bases for T'ai Chi explored.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 155; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Advanced Stagecraft
desc: The course provides practical applications of principles and techniques used in technical theatre. Lectures are supported by individually scheduled workshop sessions where techniques are applied to a theatrical production.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 160; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Stage Makeup
desc: A study of principles and techniques for stage, film, and television makeup, including corrective makeup, old age, 3-D, casting for prosthetic pieces, and methods for creating fantasy forms. Also applicable to film and television.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Introduction to Theatrical Design
desc: General principles of scenic, costume, and lighting design for the theatre.

name: Introduction to Theatre Management
desc: An overview of the major functions of management in the American nonprofit theatre including marketing, fundraising, finances, strategy and operations. Presentation skills will be practiced.

name: Period Styles for the Theatre
desc: A study of visual, cultural, and social styles through history as the forms developed, and as they relate to stylistic production for the theatre. Students may not receive credit for both DRAM 280 and DRAM 480.

name: Theatre History and Literature I
desc: Survey of theatre practice and writing from the Greeks to 1700.

name: Theatre History and Literature II
desc: Survey of theatre practice and writing from 1700 to 1920.

name: Theatre History and Literature III
desc: Survey of theatre practice and writing from 1930 to the present.

name: Studies in Dramatic Theory and Criticism
desc: May be repeated for credit. Seminar in dramatic theory and criticism with emphasis on the modern period. Honors version available
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Modern British Drama
desc: Evolution of modern British drama from 1956 through the present. Honors version available

name: Modern Irish Drama
desc: This course surveys Irish drama from the 1890s to the 1980s, investigating a broad range of plays in relationship to the sociopolitical and theatrical conditions of their emergence and reception.

name: African American Theatre
desc: This course investigates the history and legacy of African American drama through the study of its literary texts, performance styles, and cultural history.

name: Theatre for Social Change
desc: This course assesses different models of theatre for social change through change theory, playwriting, and collaboration. Students will be guided through the process of creating new works.

name: Contemporary Irish Drama
desc: This course investigates Irish drama from the 1990s to the present, exploring how issues and themes of globalization, gender, race, nation, and identity, among others, translate from text to performance. Honors version available

name: Special Topics in Dramatic Art
desc: The study of a topic in dramaturgy, theatrical design, or theatrical production. Content and instructor will vary. May be repeated for credit.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Re-Playing Shakespeare in East Asia
desc: This course investigates how Shakespeare is retold and relived in the Asian theatre vocabulary through examining aesthetic value, cultural and political identify, postcolonial modernity, and spectatorship in theatrical and cinematic interpretations of Shakespeare.

name: Corner of the Sky": The American Musical"
desc: This course considers the anatomy and diversity of the American musical, exploring its history and aesthetics and employing an interdisciplinary approach to examining and celebrating its shows, sounds, stars, structures, styles, and sensibilities, within the genre's dominant contexts of Broadway, Hollywood, and Utopia.

name: Arts Criticism
desc: An introduction to the principles of arts criticism through study of the work of a variety of critics, by distinguishing between the nature of criticism and reviewing the arts (both performing and plastic), and through the students' own practice of critical writing by means of a series of short essays.

name: African American Women in Theatre
desc: This course examines the lives of African American women through theatre, heightening awareness, understanding, and appreciation of theatre as a tool for social change and eradicating stereotypes.  Themes and production aesthetics will be explored in their social and historical contexts.

name: African Women in Theatre
desc: This course will examine the lives and the theatrical contributions of African women through published and unpublished materials, production recordings, and interviews. Through understanding the diverse cultures of the continent, theatre is seen as entertainment and as a tool for effecting social change and healing.

name: Directing
desc: Generally limited to majors. An introductory course in the principles of stage directing; analysis for concept, organization of production, and methodology of staging.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 120; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Playwriting II
desc: A practical course in writing for the theatre, taught at an advanced level.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 231; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Advanced Acting for the Major
desc: Development of the actor's technique in verse drama with emphasis on scansion and textual analysis as guidelines for actions, characterization, and given circumstances. Scene and monologue work drawn from the works of Shakespeare.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 250; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Professional Theatre Laboratory
desc: Permission of the department. Individual programs or internship in acting, directing, design, management, and playwriting under the guidance of professional practitioners in conjunction with PlayMakers Repertory Company or other professional theatre organizations.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 4 total completions.

name: Stage Management
desc: Permission of the department. A study of the basic principles and practices of modern stage management.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Sound Design
desc: The study of general principles of sound design for the theatre. Theory and application of sound design techniques for the stage, including script analysis, staging concepts, special effects, sound plots, and technology.

name: Scene Design
desc: Permission of the instructor. General principles of visual design as applied to scenery for the theatre. Instruction in standard techniques of planning and rendering scene design.

name: Costume Design I
desc: Permission of the instructor. Studies and practicum in play analysis and costume design for the theatre. Instruction in techniques of planning and rendering costume design.

name: Lighting Design I
desc: Permission of the instructor. General principles of lighting design as applied to the performing arts. Theory and instruction in standard techniques of lighting for the stage.

name: Survey of Costume History
desc: A survey of historic costume forms from ancient Egypt to the present time. Honors version available

name: Costume Construction I
desc: Permission of the instructor. Beginning instruction in pattern making through flat pattern for theatrical costume.

name: Costume Construction II
desc: Beginning instruction in pattern making through draping on a dress form for theatrical costume.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 473; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Costume History: Africa, Asia, and Arabia
desc: A survey of the traditional costume forms on the African Continent, in Asia (China, Japan, India), and on the Arabian Peninsula. Honors version available

name: Period Styles for Production
desc: A study of the historical development of Western minor arts and the ramifications of reproducing them for the theatre. Students may not receive credit for both DRAM 280 and DRAM 480.

name: Studies in Dramaturgy and Criticism
desc: This seminar seeks to introduce students to the principles of arts criticism through study of the work of a variety of different critics, by distinguishing between the nature of criticism and reviewing the arts, and through the students' own practice of critical writing.

name: Latin American Theatre
desc: This course explores the historical and aesthetic development of Latin American theatre, focusing on particular factors that distinguish this theatre from the Western European tradition.

name: United States Latino/a Theatre
desc: Investigation of United States Latino/a theatre texts and performance practices as a discreet genre. United States Latino/a theatre will be distinguished from the dominant culture, and the diversity of forms and styles will be discussed.

name: Carnivals and Festivals of the African Diaspora
desc: This course will examine the role of Carnival in the African Diaspora, exploring its history, its many theatrical forms, and its fusion with European and indigenous American cultures. Through examining published and unpublished texts the development of the Carnival will be understood as an expression of freedom and cultural survival.

name: Issues in Arts Management
desc: Arts management issues taught through analysis of case studies. Course includes management theories, organizational structures, and current issues.

name: Theatre Management
desc: Practicum in theatre management procedures and business of the theatre involving box office, audience development, research, publicity, operational, and contract procedures in regard to artists, technicians, managers, and producers. Students actively engage in management areas of the PlayMakers Repertory Company and productions of the Department of Dramatic Art.

name: Advanced Scene Design
desc: Advanced study of the principles and practice of designing scenery for the theatre.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 466; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Costume Design II
desc: Permission of the instructor. Practicum in costume design for the theatre, focusing on the requirements of professional theatre production and alternative costume design solutions.

name: Costume Seminars I: Dyeing and Painting
desc: Permission of the instructor. Taught in a four-semester rotation. May be repeated for credit for a total of six hours for undergraduates and 12 hours for graduate students. Series of topics in costume for use in design and production for the stage.

name: Costume Seminars II: Millinery and Hair
desc: Permission of the instructor. Advanced costume production techniques with an emphasis on millinery and hair design.

name: Costume Seminars III: Masks and Armor
desc: Permission of the instructor. Advanced costume production techniques with an emphasis on creating masks and armor.

name: Costume Seminars IV: Decorative Arts
desc: Permission of the instructor. Advanced costume production techniques with an emphasis on decorative arts.

name: Advanced Special Topics in Dramatic Art
desc: The study of a topic in dramaturgy, theatrical design, or theatrical production for advanced undergraduates and graduate students. Content and instructor will vary. May be repeated for credit.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Costume Production I: Couture Methods
desc: Advanced construction techniques in theatrical costuming with an emphasis on couture methods.

name: Media in Performance
desc: Required preparation, one performance studies course above COMM 400. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the required preparation.  Project-based class where students acquire skills and critical approaches to create collaborative, professional, multimedia works.

name: Costume Design for the Technician
desc: Permission of the instructor. Study of costume design for students concentrating in costume production.

name: Honors Project in Dramatic Art
desc: Required preparation, 3.3 cumulative grade point average and permission of the department. The commencement of a special project (essay or creative endeavor), approved by the department, by a student who has been designated a candidate for undergraduate honors.

name: Honors Project in Dramatic Art
desc: Permission of the department.  The completion of a special project by a student who has been designated a candidate for undergraduate honors.

name: Senior Seminar
desc: Close study of the interrelationships between theory and practice in contemporary world theatre, placing developments in their cultural contexts, and exploring current theatrical trends in an international framework.

name: Acting I
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. Acting program required. Intensive professional training for the actor. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Acting II
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Acting program required. Advanced professional training for the actor. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Voice I
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. Acting program required. Development of the individual actor's voice and speech. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Voice II
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Acting program required. Expansion of the individual's vocal versatility in performance. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Movement I
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. Acting program required. Development of the actor's body as an expressive instrument. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Movement II
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Acting program required. Advanced projects in movement. Special sessions in tumbling and stage combat. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Rehearsal and Performance I
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. Acting program required. Rehearsal and performance of special ensemble projects. Must be taken fall and spring. May be repeated for credit.

name: Rehearsal and Performance II
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Acting program required. Practical application of techniques in rehearsal and performance in studio and main stage production. Must be taken fall and spring. May be repeated for credit.

name: Acting Practicum I
desc: Admission to the third year of the M.F.A. Acting program required. Intense practicum as a member of the PlayMakers Repertory acting company. Preparation and presentation of assigned projects and work in departmental productions. Work in voice and movement as scheduled.

name: Advanced Special Studies: Costume Production II: Advanced Couture Methods
desc: Advanced construction techniques with an emphasis on advanced couture methods.

name: Special Studies: Costume Production III: Tailoring
desc: Costume graduates only. Advanced construction techniques with an emphasis on bodice development.

name: Costume Construction III: Advanced Pattern Making
desc: Study of pattern making in advanced shapes for the stage.

name: Costume Construction IV: Advanced Pattern Making
desc: Continued study of pattern making with advanced shapes for theatrical costumes.

name: Costume Construction V: Creative Draping
desc: Using combination of patternmaking and dressmaking techniques to achieve unusual shapes in theatrical costume.

name: Digital Technology in Costume Production
desc: Permission of instructor. Investigation of digital applications as applies to professional development for costume makers.

name: Period Pattern I: Pre-Victorian
desc: Permission of the instructor. Advanced study of historical pattern, costume crafts, or costume shop management through directed study. May be repeated for credit.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Period Pattern II: Victorian
desc: Costume graduates only. Study of historical pattern with an emphasis in Victorian era.

name: Period Pattern III: 20th Century
desc: Costume graduates only. Study of historical pattern with an emphasis in 20th century.

name: Period Pattern IV: 19th and 20h Century Men's Wear
desc: Costume graduates only. Study of sartorial arts with an emphasis in 19th to 20th centuries.

name: Costume Management I: Supplies and Suppliers
desc: Costume graduates only. Study of supplies and suppliers needed to produce theatrical costumes.

name: Costume Management II: Budget Methods
desc: Costume graduates only. Study of cost analysis for costume production.

name: Costume Management III: Costume Shop Management
desc: Costume graduates only. Overview of organization and personnel management for costume production.

name: Costume Laboratory I
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. Costume program required. Practical work in the costume shop. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Costume Laboratory II
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Costume program required. Advanced practical work in the costume shop. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Costume Laboratory III
desc: Costume graduates only. Continuation of practical work through production assignments.

name: Costume Laboratory IV
desc: Costume graduates only. Continuation of practical work through production assignments.

name: Costume Laboratory V
desc: Admission to the third year of the M.F.A. Costume program required. Advanced practical work in the costume shop. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Costume Laboratory VI
desc: Costume graduates only. Continuation of practical work through production assignments.

name: Costume Program Internship
desc: Intensive practicum in Costume Arts, with tutorial and class assignments on an individual basis as required. Fall or spring. May be repeated for credit.

name: Technical Direction
desc: Study of the technical and engineering problems in production and standard theatrical drafting and construction conventions. Must be taken fall and spring.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 491; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Technical Direction II
desc: Technical graduates only. Additional study of technical and engineering problems in production.

name: Advanced Technical Direction
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Technical Production program required. An advanced study of the management, technical, and engineering problems involved in theatrical production. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Advanced Technical Direction II
desc: Admission to the third year of the M.F.A. Technical Production program required. An advanced study of the management, technical, and engineering problems involved in theatrical production. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Special Studies: Technical Production
desc: Advanced scenic construction techniques leading to specific project or production responsibility in the area of scenic construction in Department of Dramatic Art productions and PlayMakers Repertory Company. A minimum of fifteen hours per week is required during the rehearsal period. Faculty evaluation at the close of the production. May be repeated for credit.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, DRAM 192; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Technical Planning and Production
desc: Admission into the third year of the M.F.A. Technical Production program required. Intensive practicum in production projects for departmental and PlayMakers Repertory Company productions. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: Special Studies: Technical Production
desc: Technical graduates only. Continuation of advanced scenic construction techniques with specific project or production responsibility in the area of scenic construction.

name: Professional Theater Laboratory: Technical Production
desc: Technical graduates only. Individual programs in scenic construction techniques.

name: Production and Facilities Management
desc: This course will teach the Technical Production Graduate Candidate and those going into administrative leadership of producing theaters a greater perspective and insight into what a Production Manager does during a season at a professional theater.

name: Advanced Lighting Design
desc: Permission of the instructor. This course acquaints the student with professional practice in lighting design through lecture by faculty and visiting professionals and through evaluation of lighting designs executed by students and critiqued by professionals.

name: Seminar in Professional Practice: Technical Production
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. program in Technical Production required. An examination of professional theatre practice through contact with students, staff, faculty, and visiting artists in technical theatre. Generally taken fall and spring. May be repeated for credit.

name: Design Technical Theatre Practicum I
desc: Admission into the M.F.A. Technical program required. Practical work in scene shop. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: M
desc: Technical graduates only. Continuation of practical work in scene shop.

name: Design Technical Theatre Practicum II
desc: Admission to the second year of the M.F.A. Technical program required. Advanced practical work in scene shop. Must be taken fall and spring.

name: M
desc: Continuation of advanced practical work in scene shop.

name: Design Technical Internship
desc: Intensive practicum in production projects for departmental and PlayMakers Repertory Company productions, with independent studies as assigned on an individual basis. May be repeated for credit.

name: Seminar in Dramatic Literature
desc: Admission to the M.F.A. program in any area required. An examination of the literature of the theatre in terms of dramatic construction, theory, and interpretation. May be repeated for credit.
